title: Lighthouse stop sending new blocks to execution layer during syncing
body:
## Description
I am using `lighthouse` as a consensus layer for eth. My execution layer - erigon

## Version

Lighthouse v3.1.0-aa022f4
BLS library: blst
SHA256 hardware acceleration: true
Specs: mainnet (true), minimal (false), gnosis (false)

## Present Behaviour

Lighthouse started long syncing process. During this time erigon node (execution layer) didn't receive blocks for more then 10 minutes. Is this is normal behavior?

Logs
```
Sep 27 10:03:29 Ubuntu-2204-jammy-amd64-base lighthouse[2332257]: Sep 27 10:03:29.001 WARN Head is optimistic                      execution_block_hash: 0x9f46a65c777a0b9ce72d7efd9954f38f4cabca5a026791766a05824d4c9f7cb0, info: chain not fully verified, block and attestat>

```

Lighthouse start command:
`lighthouse --network mainnet beacon --reconstruct-historic-states --execution-jwt /home/share/erigon/jwt.hex --execution-endpoint http://localhost:8551`

Erigon start command:
`erigon --http --http.api=eth,erigon,web3,net,debug,trace,engine --http.addr 0.0.0.0 --snapshots=false`

## Expected Behaviour

I expect that consensus layer send new block to execution layer every 10-15 seconds

Also I have a few questions:
1. Why peers searching happening so frequently and takes so much time and can ti be faster?
2. What is the meaning of `WARN Head is optimistic` logs ?

> I expect that consensus layer send new block to execution layer every 10-15 seconds

Since you're still syncing you're not importing new blocks as they come in (every ~12s). You'll notice that the sync distance is steadily increasing each slot, which means your node isn't actually importing blocks.

> Why peers searching happening so frequently and takes so much time and can ti be faster?

There's many reasons why it can be difficult to find peers. Almost all of the time it's due to some network issue. For example, a latent/intermittent internet connection, a misconfigured firewall or a lack of port-forwarding.

> What is the meaning of WARN Head is optimistic logs ?

This means that the head block has not yet been processed by the execution engine (EE). This usually happens whilst the EE is syncing. It will resolve automatically once the EE has synced.

Given that this issue was quite a while ago, I assume that you're not still having the same networking issues so I'll close this issue.
